metadata.case_name: Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. & Anr. v. State of Assam

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 is Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd., a company carrying on business of manufacturers, wholesale dealers and exporters of tea at Jalpaiguri in West Bengal. Petitioner No. 2 is M. Sudhir Chandra Guha, Manager of the company.

The company exports tea grown and manufactured in its tea garden by railway from Garopara Railway Station in Jalpaiguri district to Calcutta port. The journey traverses about 67 miles through Assam to Dhubri Ghat on River Brahmaputra, then ferries on inland waterways for 1.5 to 2 miles to Mankachar, then 572 miles through Pakistan territory, total distance 689 miles.
Assam passed Act No. 13 of 1954 taxing goods carried by road or inland waterways, which received Governor's assent on 9th April 1954.
Validity of 1954 Act challenged before Assam High Court by petitioners and other tea producers; High Court dismissed writ petitions on 6th June 1955 holding Act valid.
Appeals by special leave and writ petitions under Art. 32 heard in Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam; Supreme Court struck down 1954 Act as unconstitutional on 26th September 1960.

Assam Legislature passed Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1961 (No. 10 of 1961) with President's assent on 6th April 1961, deemed effective from 24th April 1954 till 31st March 1962.
487 persons filed writ petitions under Art. 226 before Assam High Court challenging 1961 Act; Division Bench allowed them on 1st August 1963 holding operative provisions unconstitutional.
12 petitioners from Assam High Court cases intervened in present proceedings.
Supreme Court heard Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan on 9th April 1962 clarifying Atiabari decision.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1961 is valid, particularly its operative provisions imposing tax on tea carried by road or inland waterways, in light of Arts. 301, 304(b), 19(1)(g), legislative competence under Entry 56 List II, retrospectivity, reasonableness, and public interest.
Whether the tax is compensatory in character requiring compliance only with Art. 304(b), or regulatory, and if not, whether restrictions are reasonable and in public interest under Art. 304(b).
Whether Section 3 makes producer liable even for tea sold at factory before carriage, exceeding legislative competence under Entry 56 List II.
Whether the Act can operate retrospectively under Art. 304(b).
Whether flat rate tax on weight is unreasonable restriction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Operative provisions of the Act are invalid as they directly impede freedom of trade under Art. 301, not compensatory or regulatory, and restrictions not reasonable or in public interest under Art. 304(b); also violate Art. 19(1)(g).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 301, 304(b), 19(1)(g); Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3 read with proviso to sub-s. (2) imposes tax on producer even for tea sold at factory before carriage, beyond legislative competence under Entry 56 List II.
Act cannot operate retrospectively under Art. 304(b) as it seeks to validate unconstitutional 1954 Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 304(b); Punjab Province v. Daulat Singh

petitioner_arguments.text: Flat rate tax on weight (not ton-mileage) imposes unreasonable burden; discriminatory under Art. 14; colourable legislation to validate past collections.
Act extra-territorial as petitioners in West Bengal, minimal carriage in Assam; goods not joining mass in Assam; substantially railway carriage.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 56 List II; Central India Spinning v. Municipal Committee Wardha

respondent_arguments.text: Act passed under Art. 304(b) with President's previous sanction; tax compensatory/regulatory for maintaining roads and waterways; restrictions reasonable and in public interest.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 304(b), 19(6); Automobile Transport Rajasthan Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan; Atiabari Tea Co.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 3(2) confined to producer carrying tea; proviso makes producer agent to recover from purchaser; rational nexus with carriage.
Flat rate reasonable for administrative convenience; revenue for public purposes (roads/waterways maintenance, expenditure exceeds revenue); not discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: Act not compensatory (Assam HC and counsel conceded); but restrictions reasonable and in public interest under Art. 304(b) as tax for maintaining roads/waterways used by tea/jute trade.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revenue raised serves public purpose; flat rate fair to trade as whole, avoids unfair competition.

court_reasoning.text: Legislative competence under Entry 56 List II upheld; producer liability has rational nexus with carriage for administrative convenience; power includes machinery to prevent evasion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taxable event is carriage; legislature can select assessees.

court_reasoning.text: Retrospectivity valid under Art. 304(b); taxing statutes can be retrospective if reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No bar like Art. 20(1); scheme of Part XIII not defeated.

court_reasoning.text: Onus on State to prove reasonableness/public interest once Art. 301/19(1)(g) invasion shown; State discharged onus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Saghir Ahmad v. State of U.P.

court_reasoning.text: Not extra-territorial; nexus from physical carriage in Assam; not substantially railway as ferries independent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tata Iron & Steel v. State of Bihar.

holdings.text: Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1961 valid; complies with Art. 304(b); restrictions reasonable and in public interest.
Section 3 within legislative competence under Entry 56 List II.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down earlier Act; taxes directly impeding trade attract Art. 301, sustained if comply with Art. 304(b).

precedents_cited.case_name: Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Compensatory/regulatory taxes outside Art. 301; clarified Atiabari.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saghir Ahmad v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Onus on State to justify restrictions under Art. 19(6) once invasion shown.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.C. Jall v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature can levy tax at convenient stage with rational connection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Orient Paper Mills Ltd. v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Tax power includes machinery for collection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron & Steel Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Doctrine of nexus sustains tax validity.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 304(b) permits reasonable restrictions in public interest with President's sanction; Art. 301 freedom from direct impediments; Art. 19(1)(g) protected subject to reasonable restrictions.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1961 (No. 10 of 1961)
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposes tax on tea/jute carried by road/inland waterways except rail/air; producer liable; retrospective validation.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1954 (No. 13 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Earlier invalid Act sought to be validated.

outcome.summary: Writ petition challenging validity of Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1961 dismissed; Act held constitutional under Art. 304(b) as imposing reasonable restrictions in public interest for road/waterway maintenance.

key_quotes.text: If a tax is compensatory in character, it cannot be said to fall within the mischief of Art. 301.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies from Automobile Transport case; but Act not claimed compensatory.

key_quotes.text: The power of taxing the people and their property is essential to the very existence of Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites McCulloch v. Maryland on broad taxing power subject to constitutional limits.

key_quotes.text: Once the invasion of the fundamental right under Art. 19(1) is proved, the State must justify its case under cl. (6).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Onus shifts to State per Saghir Ahmad.
